fields.headline: Warschauer Straße by Lizzie Duke
fields.bodyText: The continental trains have dining cars where cigarettes and Schnapps stagnate time - hundreds of miles of the tourist's nowhere between airports and carparks and beetfields signed off by fast-passed station names forgotten with the next and next. Every time, though, just past Ostkreuz just past Ostkreuz, before the Ostbahnhof every time it's the same: the trains, to be blunt, are like long steely cocks - oppressive and trapped in Teutonic cliché and they're coming too fast in my face as we race into town and they race away. But that's just digression, resistance, attempts to veil desire in aggression - defence against some hazy threat that the passion inspired by this seven-hour ride, uncontained will burn through the carriage or burn out, profaned with repetitive fantasy sex. Like I said, I digress, derailing all thoughts to a wilderness you, unknowing, tend.
